titleStmt.title: A true and perfect relation of the surrender of the strong and impregnable garrison the island of Scillie, to Captain Batten Vice-Admirall of the Parliaments navie at sea. VVith the discoverie of a bloody designe of Pendennis, for the blowing up of the castle, and poysoning of foure-score pieces of ordnance. Also a perfect account of the ammunition provision, and other necessaries that were left in the castle, at the surrender thereof. Together wit a list of the names of all the colonels, majors, captaines, lievtenants and other officers that were therein. VVhereunto is annexed an excellent copy of verses, made in Pendennis castle, when it was besieged by sea and land. Certified by two severall letters from Mr. Iohn Hoselock, chyrurgion to the Vice-Admirall Captain Batten in the St. Andrew. And now ptinted [sic] and published by the originall copies, according to order of Parliament.
titleStmt.author: Haslock, John.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 13 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A true and perfect RELATION OF THE Surrender of the ≈øtrong and impregnable Garri≈øon the I≈øland of SCILLIE, To Captain Batten Vice-Admirall of the Parliaments Navie at SEA.
VVITH The Di≈øcoverie of a bloody De≈øigne of Pendennis, for the blowing up of the Ca≈øtle, and poy≈øoning of foure≈øcore Pieces of Ordnance.
Al≈øo a perfect Account of the Ammunition Provi≈øion, and other nece≈ø≈øaries that were left in the Ca≈øtle at the ≈øurrender thereof.
Together with a Li≈øt of the names of all the Colonels Majors, Captaines, Lievtenants and other Officers that were therein.
VVhereunto is annexed, an excellent Copy of Ver≈øes, made in Pendennis Ca≈øtle, when it was be≈øieged by Sea and Land.

Certified by two ≈øeverall Letters from Mr. Iohn Ho≈øelock, Chyrurgion to the Vice-Admirall Captain Batten in the St. Andrew. And now Printed and publi≈øhed by the Originall Copies, according to order of PARLIAMENT.

div.head: A true Relation of the Surrender of the I≈øland of SILLY, to Capt. Batten, Vice-Admiral of the Parliaments Navie, Aug. 25. 1646.
div.p: IN my la≈øt I writ to you at large of all our proceedings at Pendennis; But ≈øince I have been in the Ca≈øtle, I can give you more true and ju≈øt account: Of which more in the en≈øuing Letter, becau≈øe I thought it meet to in≈øert in this place, the gallant proceedings of our Vice-Admirall in the reducing of the I≈øland of Silly, viz. Vpon the 24. of Augu≈øt, 1646. Some of the chiefe Commanders of the Garri≈øon of the I≈øland of Silly, (having before ≈øent a Trumpetter to the Vice-admirall for a Treaty, came aboord the Andrew, where they laid open and pre≈øented their propo≈øitions for the ≈øurrendring of that I≈øland. Where, after ≈øome con≈øultation between the Vice-admirall and the re≈øt of his Officers, their earne≈øt reque≈øts were admitted, and immediatly began to debate upon the Articles, and at la≈øt concluded that the Garri≈øon and I≈øland of Silly, with all the Ordnance, Armes, and Ammunition, ≈øhould bee ≈øurrendred to Captain Batten, Vice-admirall of the Parliaments Navie, upon the 25. of Augu≈øt, 1646.

div.head: A true Relation of the ≈øurrender of Pendennis and the I≈øland of Scillie.
div.p:
Loving Frend the well wi≈øhes of a friend be≈øides this, the≈øe may as well certifie you of our health as of the ≈øurrender of Pendennis Ca≈øtle to Colonell Forte≈øcue and our Commanders, the verye truth is, they would not have yeelded to the Colonell, but to auoyde contention the Admirall de≈øired they would treaty with both which tretie at fir≈øt did not hold for they had no mind to the land forces (neither valued them) as in my hearing the governor of the Ca≈øtle told the Admirall, (but as ≈øure as may be at the breaking of the fir≈øt treatie they went into the Ca≈øtle and took on oath (all the Gentrey) to ≈øplit the ordinance of which we have found foure≈øcore and odd, and to blow upp the Ca≈øtle and ≈øoe to fall upon the land forces to live and die together, this you may verye credible reporte for I hove heard it from the mouthes of the be≈øt of them and and Sir Henry Kilegrew my patient with home I was two howers before they ≈øurenderd to us, but the prevention of this plot was by meanes of the Admirall, for he had ≈øoe wrought with ≈øome that came a bord, that he put all the Souldiers in a mutinie, and by this meanes Digbie and his crew could not performe there bloody de≈øigne, and ≈øoe they came again to treate (and ≈øurrendred the 17. Day there was (noe bread) not drink onely a litle water nor meat only a ca≈øk of hor≈øe ≈øalted but pouder and ≈øhot enough, we had taken there be≈øt ≈øhallop from them
that no other dur≈øt venter to them I beleeve there is betwixt 3 and 400 ≈øicke left behind, the re≈øt are matcht to their homes, only ≈øome that are to be tran≈øported into france, ha≈øt calls a way but I hope to prattle more with thee over a pin ‚Ä¢ e ≈øhortly, therefore only remembering my love to father Hadley ma≈øtarwarton, Brother Baker and all the hone≈øt crew I re≈øt.

div.head: A Li≈øt of the Officers and Souldiers belonging to Pendennis Ca≈øtle at the ≈øurrender thereof.
div.p: Of all the≈øe there is upward of three hundred

lg.l: LAdy Penelope, faire Queen, mo≈øt cha≈øt
Pendeunis, of all Royall Forts the la≈øt,
The la≈øt the only Fort nere conquered was
Nere ≈øhall be, who in con≈øtancy doth pa≈ø≈øe
The re≈øt of all thy ≈øi≈øters, who to thee
(The enlips of all the Kinde) but ≈øtrumpets be:
Great Fairfax. ≈øonne of Mars, Bellonaes love
Who≈øe victories ≈øhe prizes highly, farre above
Cae≈øars: pre≈øents the Trophies: and renowne
Promi≈øing the Queen of Forts a Triple Crowne
Scorne the high Climbering Pharton; or let the ≈øunne
Thy hu≈øband be; or be for aye, a Rune
Brave Hamond Coveteous is, but cannot ≈øpeed
But Forte≈øcue as har≈øh, of him take heed
He that ≈øo dogged is: now hees a wooing,
His ≈øuite once granted: will be thy undoing
If now the man his humor cannot hide
Wi≈øe Abegall, his ≈øuite will not abide
Batten In's floating Ca≈øtle; Neptune like
For love of thee; His lofty ≈øayles would ≈øtrike
Become thy Captaine (might it be his hap)
Thou ≈øhoulde≈øt fall fa≈øt: into faire Thetes lap.
Or where they love: forth Indies to be ≈øold
Heed danas Bo≈øome fill with ≈øhowres of Gold
Heed court his Lady; like a filver ≈øwan
Vpon the mayne; nor ≈øhould there be a man
In's winged fleet; that ≈øhould not ≈øpeak thee faire
But with his cannon thunderings in the aire
Would make the mu≈øick, and withall to wonder
To here him ≈øpeake ≈øo ≈øweetly and to thunder,
Weepe not;, as one for≈øaken; and forlone
Thine owne Vly≈ø≈øes; will in time returne
Embrace and hugge the in his Royall Armes
Ne're conquered yet by force or woon by charmes
Brave Governor; be ≈øtill but what thou art
England may be ≈øubdued er'e thy great heart
